HyperUI is a collection of free, open-source UI components built with Tailwind CSS. It provides a set of basic components and templates that can be used to quickly prototype and build web interfaces.

Use HyperUI when you need a simple and lightweight set of UI components for your Tailwind CSS project. It's suitable for projects where you want to quickly prototype or build basic UI elements without relying on a large component library.

Avoid HyperUI if you require a component library with a wide range of advanced components or extensive customization options. Also, if you prefer a component library with built-in theming capabilities, HyperUI might not be the best choice.
🚀
HyperUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
HyperUI has 24 Components, 19 of them are unique – for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
HyperUI has light and dark themes
Does not support more than 2 themes at the same time
HyperUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
HyperUI has no dependencies, but it requires @tailwindcss/forms plugin
HyperUI uses Tailwind CSS class names which is available on CDN
HyperUI does not use semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
HyperUI requires changing class names one by one at build time to do customization
HyperUI does not requires a Node.js environment
HyperUI does not provide micro CSS files for each component
HyperUI uses wide-gamut P3 colors by default
HyperUI customizations requires changing Tailwind CSS class names at build time
HyperUI doesn not use native CSS nesting

daisyUI is a component library for Tailwind CSS that provides pre-designed components with theming capabilities. It is framework-agnostic, meaning it can be used in any web project, and it doesn't ship any JavaScript to the browser.

Use daisyUI when you want to rapidly prototype or build a project with a consistent design system based on Tailwind CSS. It's well-suited for projects where you need a large variety of customizable components and theme options without writing a lot of custom CSS.

Avoid daisyUI if you need highly specific or unique component designs that deviate significantly from the pre-designed styles. Also, if you prefer to build all components from scratch for maximum control over every detail, daisyUI might not be the best choice.
daisyUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
daisyUI has 61 components, 57 of them are unique – for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
daisyUI supports unlimited themes at the same time, allowing for dynamic theme switching.
daisyUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
daisyUI has no dependencies. It's immune to 3rd party vulnerabilities, dependency version mismatch, and deprecation issues.
In GitHub's top 400 repositories of all time
daisyUI CSS file is available on CDN
daisyUI uses semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
daisyUI provides tokens, root-level CSS variables and component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
daisyUI can be used as a standalone file, with Tailwind CSS standalone version. This is useful for projects without a Node.js environment.
daisyUI provides micro CSS files for each component
daisyUI uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
daisyUI uses native CSS nesting, reducing the CSS file size
Key differences between daisyUI and HyperUI

Both libraries are well-regarded. daisyUI has gained more stars than HyperUI, reflecting its growing popularity. HyperUI offers various UI elements. daisyUI provides a broader range of UI elements. daisyUI operates as a standalone Tailwind CSS plugin without dependencies
HyperUI offers various UI elements. daisyUI provides a broader range of UI elements.
The 35 themes in daisyUI offer more variety than the 2 provided by HyperUI.
Both libraries are well-regarded. daisyUI has gained more stars than HyperUI, reflecting its growing popularity. daisyUI serves a large number of users, as seen from its NPM download statistics
Both libraries are well-regarded. daisyUI has gained more stars than HyperUI, reflecting its growing popularity.
daisyUI serves a large number of users, as seen from its NPM download statistics.
daisyUI operates as a standalone Tailwind CSS plugin without dependencies.
If you use HyperUI, you might appreciate how daisyUI integrates directly with Tailwind CSS classes for styling components, offering a CSS-based alternative.
